questions.prompt: What is the primary purpose of data replication?
questions.explanation: Data replication maintains multiple copies of data across different nodes, improving availability (data accessible despite failures) and fault tolerance (surviving failures).

options: All reads see the most recent write
questions.explanation: Strong consistency (also called linearizability) guarantees that all reads return the value of the most recent write, making the system appear as if there is only one copy of the data.

questions.prompt: What tradeoff does eventual consistency make?
questions.explanation: Eventual consistency allows replicas to temporarily diverge (sacrificing immediate consistency) to remain available, guaranteeing only that replicas will converge if updates stop.

options: All clients see all updates immediately
A client sees their own updates immediately
questions.explanation: Read-your-writes (also called read-after-write) consistency guarantees that a client will always see their own updates, even if other clients might see stale data temporarily.

options: Reads never go backwards in time
questions.explanation: Monotonic reads guarantee that if a client reads a value, any subsequent reads will see that value or a more recent one, never an older value.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between primary-backup and multi-primary replication?
options: Primary-backup has one writer, multi-primary has many
questions.explanation: Primary-backup replication has a single primary that handles all writes, while multi-primary allows multiple nodes to accept writes, increasing complexity but enabling geo-distribution.

questions.prompt: What is a quorum in distributed systems?
options: Minimum number of nodes needed for an operation
questions.explanation: A quorum is the minimum number of nodes that must participate in an operation (read or write) to ensure consistency. Typically a majority to guarantee overlap between operations.

questions.prompt: In quorum-based replication with N replicas, what is a common quorum size?
questions.explanation: A majority quorum (N/2 + 1) ensures that any two quorums overlap, guaranteeing that reads will see recent writes. This allows tolerating N/2 failures while maintaining consistency.

questions.prompt: What are CRDTs (Conflict-free Replicated Data Types)?
options: Data structures that merge automatically without conflicts
questions.explanation: CRDTs are data structures designed to be replicated across nodes where concurrent updates can be merged automatically without conflicts, enabling strong eventual consistency.

questions.prompt: What property must CRDT merge operations satisfy?
questions.explanation: CRDT merges must be commutative (order doesn't matter), associative (grouping doesn't matter), and idempotent (applying twice has same effect), enabling automatic conflict resolution.

questions.prompt: What is an example of a state-based CRDT?
questions.explanation: State-based CRDTs (like grow-only counters, grow-only sets) share entire state and merge using a semilattice structure, where merging is the join operation.

options: CRDTs that share operations instead of state
questions.explanation: Operation-based CRDTs share operations (like "increment", "add element") instead of full state. Operations must commute, and typically require causal delivery of operations.

options: Consistency guarantees within a single client session
questions.explanation: Session consistency provides consistency guarantees (like read-your-writes, monotonic reads) within a single client session, but not across different clients or sessions.

questions.prompt: What is the advantage of async replication over sync replication?
questions.explanation: Asynchronous replication doesn't wait for acknowledgment from replicas before confirming writes, providing lower latency and better availability, though risking data loss on failures.

options: Operations appear to execute atomically at some point between invocation and response
questions.explanation: Linearizability (the strongest consistency model) requires that operations appear to execute instantaneously at some point between their invocation and response, with a total order consistent with real-time.
